issues.text: Whether the Aligarh Muslim University was established by the Muslim minority entitling it to the right to administer under Article 30(1) of the Constitution, rendering the 1951 and 1965 Amendment Acts ultra vires Article 30(1)

anchor.surface_text: The principal attack is based on the provisions of Art. 30 1  which lays down that all minorities whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice. holdings.text: The Aligarh Muslim University was established by the Central Legislature by enacting the Aligarh Muslim University Act, 1920, and not by the Muslim minority.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to our mind as to who established the Aligarh University is clear and that is that it was the Central Legislature by enacting the 19

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of 1920 Act: long title, preamble, s.4 dissolution and vesting, s.6 degree recognition only possible via statute; historical context shows minority could not compel govt recognition of degrees.

holdings.text: The words 'establish and administer' in Article 30(1) must be read conjunctively, giving minorities the right to administer only educational institutions established by them.

anchor.surface_text: The words establish and administer in the Article must be read conjunctively and so read it gives the right to the minority to administer an educational institution provided it has been established by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation rejects disjunctive reading; distinguishes Kerala Education Bill as not supporting administration without establishment; applies to both Art.30(1) and Art.26(a).

precedents.citation: In re, The Kerala Education Bill, 1957 1

anchor.surface_text: In re, The Kerala Education Bill, 1957 1 where, it is argued, this Court had held that the minority can administer an educational institution even though it might not have established it. In that case an argument was raised that under Art. 30(1) protection was given only to educational institutions established after the Constitution came into force. That argument was turned down by this Court for the obvious reason that if that interpretation was given to Art. 30(1) it would be robbed of much of its content. But that case in our opinion did not lay down that the words 'establish, and administer' in Art 30(1) should be read disjunctively, so that, though a minority might not have established an educational institution it had the right to administer it. It is true that at p. 1062 the Court spoke of Art. 30(1) giving two rights to a minority i.e. (i) to establish and (ii) to administer. But that was said only in the context of meeting the argument that educational institutions established by minorities before the Constitution came into force did not have the protection of Art. 30(1). We are of opinion that nothing in that case justifies the contention raised on behalf of the petitioners that the minorities would have the right to administer an educational institution even though the institution may not have been established, by them. The two words in Art 30(1) must be read together and so read the Article gives this right to the minority to administer institutions established by it.

precedents.cited_proposition: minority can administer an educational institution even though it might not have established it; words 'establish' and 'administer' in Art. 30(1) give two rights
precedents.cited_holding: Art. 30(1) protects pre-Constitution minority institutions; spoke of right to establish and right to administer

precedents.citation: The purgah Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali 1

anchor.surface_text: The purgah Committee, Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali 1. In that case the Court observed while dealing with Art. 26(a) and (d) of the Constitution that even if it be assumed that a certain religious institution was established by a minority community it may lose the right to administer it in certain circumstances. We may in this connection refer to the following observations at p. 414 for they apply equally to Art. 30(1): "If the right to administer properties never vested in the denomination or had been validly surrendered by it or had otherwise been effectively and irretrievably lost to it, Art. 26 cannot be successfully invoked."

precedents.case_name: Pargah Committee Ajmer v. Syed Hussain Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: even if a religious institution was established by a minority community it may lose the right to administer it if the right never vested, was surrendered, or lost; applies to Art. 26 and equally to Art. 30(1)
precedents.cited_holding: "If the right to administer properties never vested in the denomination or had been validly surrendered by it or had otherwise been effectively and irretrievably lost to it, Art. 26 cannot be successfully invoked."

precedents.citation: St. Davids College, Lampeter v. Ministry of Education 1

anchor.surface_text: St. Davids College, Lampeter v. Ministry of Education 1. Thus in law in India there was no prohibition against establishment of universities by private individuals or bodies and if any university was so established it must of necessity be granting degrees before it could be called a university. But though such a university might be granting degrees it did not follow that the Government of the country was bound to recognise those degrees.

precedents.case_name: St. Davids College Lampeter v. Ministry of Education
precedents.cited_proposition: what distinguishes a university from any other educational institution is that a university grants degrees of its own while other educational institutions cannot

anchor.surface_text: The petitions therefore fail and are hereby dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petitions under Article 32 challenging the constitutionality of Aligarh Muslim University Amendment Acts of 1951 and 1965 dismissed; the Acts upheld as constitutional and within legislative competence.
